data.title: Fix the #if statement in OcclusionQuery.cs so the mac port will build
Fix MacOS build and relax GL errors to get MacOS running
data.body:
The change to the TextureTarget fixes the build, but it seems that there are some problems on Mac with the GL error checking that @slygamer added recently. 

In particular, it's uncovered the fact that we are running some GL calls before the frame buffer is created and getting InvalidFrameBuffer error at startup in a few places. I've opted simply to relax the errors to get Mac samples running again rather than fix the underlying cause (could be a rabbit warren!).

data.body:

Moved the new Linux and MacOSX projects for the AddIn into the new directory and updated the solution.

It's asking for MonoDevelop.IDE v2.4. What's weird to me was the fact that everything works fine on my windows desktop. Normally I would just use that but my windows desktop is getting pretty old and slow and I really would prefer to do everything on my MacBook Pro Late 2011 as much as possible.

What confused me was it asking me for MonoDevelop.IDE v2.4. Does that mean I have to use that old of a version of MonoDevelop? I'm pretty sure I'm missing something. Can anyone help?

data.title: PSMobile solution doesn't compile (due to conditional compilation in ConstantBufferCollection.cs)
data.body:
The PSMobile solution cannot build successfully.

In the ConstantBufferCollection class, conditional compilation is used.

Only OPENGL or DIRECTX are used, and so this results in malformed code in case of PSMobile, for example:
# if DIRECTX

```
    internal void SetConstantBuffers(GraphicsDevice device)
```
# elif OPENGL

```
    internal void SetConstantBuffers(GraphicsDevice device, int shaderProgram)
```
# endif

```
    {
        // If there are no constant buffers then skip it.
        if (_valid == 0)
            return;
```

none of the conditional symbols match, and so the method begins with the { character.

data.body:

Requires merge of 3rd-party libs first....

... once that is merged let me know and i'll add the submodule reference to this pull and it can all be merged.

data.title: Ray-Plane intersect/WinRT ScreenSizeChange viewport fix
data.body:
Two fixes in this:

1) In XNA, when the OnClientSizeChanged() has been called, the GraphicsDevice.Viewport field has been updated to the new bounds of the screen. It wasn't in MonoGame, so we need to set the viewport before triggering the callback. I know that the applychanges() below the code I've entered sets the viewport, but it needs to be done earlier so that clients can have access to the new viewport bounds as the callback happens. This change fixes that.

2) Ray.Intersect(Plane) wasn't implemented correctly. It didn't account for the offset of the plane, so any Ray.Intersect(plane) test was against the 0 plane.

data.title: Fixed missing clamp from color multiply
data.body: Color.White*1.000001f resulted in (0,0,0,0) instead of (255,255,255,255).

data.title: Bug fix (#563)
data.body:
Hi,

Please review this change to resolve issue #563.

Basically, when drawing using this particular spritebatch overload, DestinationRectangle can be larger than the source rectangle.

This can lead to cases such as described in that issue, where the origin is not being scaled right.

Previously, origin was used as a dx, dy, however this needs to be scaled according to the difference in sizes of the dest/src rectangle.

Please review this as it touches a pretty "popular" class (SpriteBatch).

I created a sample project and loaded an mp3 music file in the loadcontent method, then i call 

someSoundEffect.play() 
and nothing happens.

i then tried to give the player some time to build buffer, say 15 seconds, and the music actually plays around 5 seconds then hangs and stops completely.
Can anyobne confirm this is a common issue?
I tried almost every file format: wav,mp3,ogg but everyone gives the same kind of weird behaviour.

data.title: Add iOS6 compatibility
data.body:
iOS 6 introduced a change to the way rotation is handled. This means, that we need to implement some new functions:

```
GetSupportedInterfaceOrientations
ShouldAutorotate
PreferredInterfaceOrientationForPresentation
```

these will be used instead of the function

```
ShouldAutorotateToInterfaceOrientation
```

on iOS 6.

There is also a change in the use of the info.plist's orientation settings: They always should be all but portrait upside down for iPhone, and all for iPad. If you don't match these settings and try to use gamecenter for example, your app will crash. This means that we need to depend on the XNA variable for supported resolutions, and drop the support for parsing the orientations from the Info.plist. Please note that this applies for XCode 4.5, even if building for iOS5! (drove me ntus)

This change also introduced a bug-like behaviour: Applications start with portrait resolutions, no matter what is set in the Info.plist, then it changes those back to normal accidentally. Some cocos developers referenced this as swapped width/height. Apple did not seem to care about this issue, so we need to adapt. This led to a number of cases where we end up working with the wrong resolutions.

I would also like to note that iOS6 seemed to increase the trampoline type 2 usage, which resulted in our game crashing with default trampoline count.

data.title: Windows 8 - Issue with SoundEffectInstance
data.body:
In XNA, if you call Play() on a SoundEffectInstance while it's playing--it does nothing.

In MonoGame/Windows 8, it stops the sound and starts it over.  Which causes some weird issues with sound in our game.  It is possible we are using sounds in an unexpected manner, though.

I have created a repro here: https://github.com/jonathanpeppers/SoundEffectInstanceRepro

There are two solutions: plain XNA as well as MonoGame/Windows 8.

Comments are present because I wasn't sure about some things and I was
hoping those more familiar with this part of the API can provide
feedback.  I will clean it up in a future commit.

data.title: [Linux] [2.5 branch] Font rendering
Made Texture2D.Reload(Stream) public
data.body: This method was always intended to be public. It provides a way for textures that were not loaded through a `ContentManager` (ie via `Texture2D.FromStream()`) to be reloaded when the GL context is lost on Android. Obviously you could just reload them using `Texture2D.FromStream()` again, but the advantage of using this method is that it avoids the need to update all references to the texture throughout your code.

data.title: Fixed android texture reloading [TESTING AND COMMENT REQUESTED]
data.body:
I just managed to get this working again (FINALLY!).

It was the changes to Texture2D.cs that did it... regenerating the textures with GL.GenTextures and GL.TexParamater. I don't understand why it used to work without this step though... =| 

I used the DeviceResetting event to set `glTexture = -1`. Despite the fact that this event is actually run after the Android GL Context is recreated, it's still a useful way to run a group of event handlers before the DeviceReset is handled.

For now, I've just submitted this PR with all my attempts to fix the problem included. I think most of them are worth-while additions (resetting state in GraphicsDevice etc), but if people would rather I cut it down to a minimal set of changes to fix this issue, I'm happy to do that too.

So far I haven't tested this on any platforms other than Android.

data.title: Removed call to Threading.EnsureUIThread() under WinRT
data.body: This fixes the build under WinRT.

data.title: Parameters not the same between XNA and MGFX
Same EffectParameter In VS and PS Doesn't Update
data.body:
From codeplex...

"If I have an effect parameter that's used both in the Vertex Shader and the Pixel Shader, it goes in two constant buffers, but when it's set in the first buffer (probably the VS one) the dirty flag goes away and it's never updated in the PS's buffer."

http://monogame.codeplex.com/discussions/396601

data.title: TouchPanel.IsGestureAvailable Bug
data.body:
Description:

TouchPanel.IsGestureAvailable appears not to be getting updated when new events occur.

Repro:
Create new MonoGame Win8 RT project
Create new XNA 4.0 WP7 game

Add a using:
using Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Input.Touch;

Add to the Initialize before the base call:
TouchPanel.EnabledGestures = GestureType.Hold | GestureType.Tap | GestureType.DoubleTap | GestureType.Flick | GestureType.VerticalDrag | GestureType.HorizontalDrag;

Add to the update method before the base call:
           while (TouchPanel.IsGestureAvailable)
            {
                GestureSample gesture = TouchPanel.ReadGesture();
            }

Put breakpoint on the GestureSample line...

Run...
Create Gestures on screen...

Expected Result...
Breakpoint hit

Result
Breakpoint not hit.

WP7 breaks as expected.

Root casue?
Seems TouchPanel.IsGestureAvailable is not updated

Work Around:

TouchCollection touches = TouchPanel.GetState();

The above appears to force an update of TouchPanel.

MSDN doc:
http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ff827740.aspx

Kind Regards
